head.title: Epistle. Amintor to Fidelia.1, 1 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 19-22; reprinted as “Epistle Amintor to Fidelia, Pastoral Elegy, by Mr. G. Turnbull of the Church-street Theatre” in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 12, 1796).2, 2 Amintor is the name of the young courtier in and hero of Francis Beaumont and John Fletcher’s The Maid’s Tragedy (1619).33 Latin for faithful, Fidelia was often the name of heroines in seventeenth-century romance.

lg.l: Stretch’d on a bed, where languishing I lie,
No pitying friend, no kind companion nigh;
Not joy’d, but thankful for the morning light,
These melancholy lines to thee I write;
Only to tell the torments I endure,
I hope for pity, but expect no cure:
Ah, wretched thought! beyond relief I see
Thee, charming maid, lost to thyself and me.
Since last we parted, many a joyless day
And dreary night has slowly crept away:
Time with the happy, flies with furious speed,
But lamely crawls with wretchedness indeed!
Each night denied the blessing of repose,
And morning rais’d me to succeeding woes;
Yet still a ray of hope would intervene,
And faintly cheer the melancholy scene;
But rob’d of that sweet soother of my care,
What now remains for me but wild despair!
As once, worn out with never-ending grief,
Unwonted slumber brought its kind relief;
Fair to my morbid fancy was display’d
The form of thee, all sweetly pensive laid
Within a frowning husband’s eager arms;
The undeserving master of thy charms.
Amaz’d I stood, and fix’d on both my eyes;
And thou, as eager gaz’d in strong surprize;
Attempting oft, methought, my sight to shun,
Too conscious of the wrong that thou hadst done.
Not many days elaps’d, when, oh dire tale!
These heavy accents did my ears assail;
That thou, to one thou ever didst despise,
For wealth had yielded up thyeslf a prize!
If thou, Fidelia, ever felt for me
The tender flame I’ve cherish’d still for thee,
Then mayst thou know what passions tore my breast,
When these unwelcome tidings were express’d:
’Twixt love and rage the dire contention hung,
Strength left my limbs, and speech forsook my tongue;
My soul with anguish torn—resentment gone,
I find relief in sorrow’s drops alone.
Of all the woes that wretched man befal,
Sure, disappointment is the worst of all!
Time’s lenient hand may other griefs remove,
But never cure the wounds of hopeless love.
Not all that fell ambition e’er ador’d—
Not all the wealth that Indian mines afford44 Poetic trope for jewels.—
Not all the grandeur of an eastern throne,
Could for the loss of thee, dear maid, atone.
Where now are all the prospects fancy drew,
When smiling hope on wings seraphic flew?
The hours of transport, years of true delight,
The joyous day and more enchanting night,
That should my triumph and my wishes crown,
When I could call Fidelia all my own?
Our time in mutual transport to employ,
And live but to encrease each other’s joy;
To chace from thy fair brow the clouds of care,
Thy griefs to banish, and thy pleasures share,
To see like flow’rs a blooming offspring rise,
The care and comfort of our aged eyes!

But ah, vain hope!55 “But, ah! vain hope, two deadly foes / The heath’s wild honours claim” from “Acasto: An Elegiac Pastoral,” The Scots Magazine, vol. 37 (March, 1775), p. 153. why didst thou thus betray,
Why didst thou lead my simple heart astray?
So oft deluded by thy hony’d tongue,
No more I’ll listen to thy syren song!
Of ev’ry false delusion hence beware,
And fall a willing victim to despair.
Sweet maid, farewel! and all delight adieu!
A wretch forlorn life’s journey I’ll pursue;
Pleasure in vain her gilded baits shall throw,
To lure me from my lethargy of woe.
Bat O! may ev’ry happiness attend
My lov’d Fidelia, once my faithful friend!
Though fortune and stern fate’s supreme decree
Yet reluctantly, hath snatch’d thee from me;
So long as life shall warm this wretched frame,
My love shall unimpaird remain the same!
And when remembrance shall past scenes renew,
And bring departed happiness to view;
For thee, alone, the silent tears shall flow,
And joy shall mingle with the drops of woe.
